titleInfo.title: Music Therapy Master's Equivalency
titleInfo.subTitle: A Synthesis of Current University Websites

mods:mods.abstract: The purpose of this study was to examine the current state of music therapy master's equivalency (MTME) university websites with the goals of identifying what information is publicly available, the user-friendliness of these websites, and make research-based conclusions on the potential user experience of the public and prospective students on MTME websites. A descriptive emphasis was placed on current graduate level music therapy admissions, available degree program information, and overall website design. Additionally, the objective experience while examining websites was documented and analyzed. Universities (N=37) were identified using the American Music Therapy Association's (AMTA) organization directory search (American Music Therapy Association, n.d.-g). The qualifier 'equivalency masters offered' was applied to identify universities offering MTME programs. The results of this study identified the current availability of MTME degree programs and their distribution across the United States. Nearly half of the universities examined offered additional non-music therapy related training which are referred to as 'music therapy plus' by the researcher. Further results revealed a majority of MTME websites had unclear or unlisted projected program timelines. Similarly, a majority of MTME programs did not publish music therapy handbooks, information on field specific materials or additional costs, or define the tuition type for their program's equivalency portion (either undergraduate or graduate credit hours). Finally, the researcher's objective experience collecting data revealed that on average it took 14 minutes to find information needed on each MTME university website, and in total, 220 clicks (individual URLs) were recorded to research all MTME programs examined. Findings may provide insight for future online recruitment and public communication in music therapy education. Moreover, the findings may be useful to assess areas of university website improvements to support a user-friendly experience for the public and prospective students who may be new to the field of music therapy. Further results and implications are discussed within this thesis.
mods:mods.note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Music Therapy in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Music.
Lori Gooding, Professor Directing Thesis; Jayne Standley, Committee Member; Flor del Cielo Hernandez, Committee Member.
